lines.content: * Represents a task that needs to be completed by a specific date and time.
* A {@code Deadline} extends the {@link Task} class by adding a single due date
* (the "by" time). It handles the parsing of this date from a specific input string
* and formats it differently for file storage versus user display.
/** The due date and time of the deadline. */
* Constructs a {@code Deadline} task with a description and a due date.
* The date string provided must strictly follow the format "d/M/yyyy HHmm"
* @param description The description of the deadline task.
* @param by          The due date string in "d/M/yyyy HHmm" format.
* @throws java.time.format.DateTimeParseException if the date string does not match the expected format.
* Returns a formatted string suitable for storage in a data file.
* The format follows the pattern: {@code D | [status] | [description] | [by]}.
* The date is stored in the "d/M/yyyy HHmm" format to ensure consistency during reloading.
* @return The data string representation of the deadline.
* Returns the string representation of the deadline for display to the user.
* The output includes the type marker "[D]", the task status, description,
* and the due date formatted nicely (e.g., "MMM dd yyyy h:mm a").
* @return The formatted string representation of the deadline.
DateTimeFormatter outputFormatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy h:mm a", Locale.US);
* Represents a task that occurs during a specific time period.
* An {@code Event} extends the {@link Task} class by adding a start time
* and an end time. It handles date-time parsing and formatting for both
/** The start time of the event. */
/** The end time of the event. */
* Constructs an {@code Event} task with a description, start time, and end time.
* The date strings provided must strictly follow the format "d/M/yyyy HHmm"
* @param description The description of the event task.
* @param from        The start time string in "d/M/yyyy HHmm" format.
* @param to          The end time string in "d/M/yyyy HHmm" format.
* @throws java.time.format.DateTimeParseException if the date strings do not match the expected format.
public Event(String description, String from, String to) {
* Returns a formatted string suitable for storage in a data file.
* The format follows the pattern: {@code E | [status] | [description] | [from] | [to]}.
* The dates are stored in the "d/M/yyyy HHmm" format to ensure consistency during reloading.
* @return The data string representation of the event.
* Returns the string representation of the event for display to the user.
* The output includes the type marker "[E]", the task status, description,
* and the time interval formatted nicely (e.g., "MMM dd yyyy h:mm a").
* @return The formatted string representation of the event.
DateTimeFormatter outputFormatter = DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern("MMM dd yyyy h:mm a", Locale.US);

* This class encapsulates an {@code ArrayList} of {@link Task} objects and provides
* methods to manipulate the list, such as adding, deleting, and retrieving tasks.
* Constructs a {@code TaskList} initialized with a pre-existing list of tasks.
* @param tasks An {@code ArrayList} of {@link Task} objects to initialize the list with.
* Adds a new task to the list.
* @param task The {@link Task} object to be added.

* @param index The zero-based index of the task to be removed.
* @throws IndexOutOfBoundsException if the index is out of range.
* Retrieves the task at the specified position in the list.
* @param index The zero-based index of the task to return.
* @return The {@link Task} at the specified position.
* @throws IndexOutOfBoundsException if the index is out of range.
* Returns the number of tasks in the list.
* @return The number of tasks in the list.

* a description and a completion status. It does not have a deadline or an
* Constructs a {@code Todo} task with the specified description.

* The output includes the type marker "[T]", followed by the standard
* @return The formatted string representation of the todo task.
* Returns a formatted string suitable for storage in a data file.
* The format follows the pattern: {@code T | [status] | [description]}.

* Handles all interactions with the user.
* This class encapsulates the details of reading input from the standard input
* and printing formatted messages to the standard output. It ensures consistent
* visual presentation (indentation and divider lines) across the application.
* Constructs a new {@code Ui} instance and initializes the input scanner.

* The message is prefixed with "OOPS!!!" to indicate an exception or invalid input.
